citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The buffalo bull on the safari is missing large spots of fur on this back end. He is missing hair completely on his rump
around the base of his tail and the skin looks crusty. On his back and sides, the fur is missing in multiple circular patches.
The licensee had noticed the hairloss but had not contacted his vet to see if treatment was needed. Animals can lose hair
due to a variety of conditions that can be itchy, painful, or uncomfortable. If the hairloss continues, the animal may not be
able to acclimate to seasonal changes. Animals must be observed daily and any abnormal conditions communicated to
the attending veterinarian in a timely manner. Correct by contacting the vet and following their recommendations by
9/18/25.

The guinea pigs are being housed in an outdoor corral. The temperature during the inspection was 82-90 degrees.
Guinea pigs are very sensitive to temperature and humidity and can quickly become ill when exposed to extremes.
Guinea pigs cannot be housed outside unless the facility is located in an appropriate climate and has prior approval from
the Deputy Administrator. Correct by 9/21/25 by housing the guinea pigs indoors or obtaining approval.

The facility is thawing a large box of frozen chicken breasts uncovered, outside on the deck. The temperatures during the
inspection ranged from 82-90 degrees. This chicken was intended for feeding to servals, caracals, lynx, and other
carnivores that evening. The edges of the box had already thawed but the middle was still frozen solid. The licensee
states this is usually how they thaw the chicken until they can break it apart and then smaller portions are placed in the
mini fridge until they are fed out. Thawing meat this way causes uneven thawing, allowing the outside portion that thawed
first to grow harmful bacteria, start to deteriorate, and attract pests such as flies. Additionally, thawing outside on an
uncovered deck can lead to contamination by dirt and debris and attract unwanted animals. Food must be wholesome,
palatable, and free from contamination. Correct by 9/16/25 by ensuring meat stays frozen or refrigerated until it is being
prepped and fed out.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensees.
Additional Inspectors:
Moira Roberts, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The buffalo bull on the safari is missing large spots of fur on this back end. He is missing hair completely on his rump 
around the base of his tail and the skin looks crusty. On his back and sides, the fur is missing in multiple circular patches. 
The licensee had noticed the hairloss but had not contacted his vet to see if treatment was needed. Animals can lose hair 
due to a variety of conditions that can be itchy, painful, or uncomfortable. If the hairloss continues, the animal may not be 
able to acclimate to seasonal changes. Animals must be observed daily and any abnormal conditions communicated to 
the attending veterinarian in a timely manner. Correct by contacting the vet and following their recommendations by 
9/18/25. 
3.27(b) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The guinea pigs are being housed in an outdoor corral. The temperature during the inspection was 82-90 degrees. 
Guinea pigs are very sensitive to temperature and humidity and can quickly become ill when exposed to extremes. 
Guinea pigs cannot be housed outside unless the facility is located in an appropriate climate and has prior approval from 
the Deputy Administrator. Correct by 9/21/25 by housing the guinea pigs indoors or obtaining approval. 
3.129(a) 
   
Feeding. 
The facility is thawing a large box of frozen chicken breasts uncovered, outside on the deck. The temperatures during the 
inspection ranged from 82-90 degrees. This chicken was intended for feeding to servals, caracals, lynx, and other 
carnivores that evening. The edges of the box had already thawed but the middle was still frozen solid. The licensee 
states this is usually how they thaw the chicken until they can break it apart and then smaller portions are placed in the 
mini fridge until they are fed out. Thawing meat this way causes uneven thawing, allowing the outside portion that thawed 
first to grow harmful bacteria, start to deteriorate, and attract pests such as flies. Additionally, thawing outside on an 
uncovered deck can lead to contamination by dirt and debris and attract unwanted animals. Food must be wholesome, 
palatable, and free from contamination. Correct by 9/16/25 by ensuring meat stays frozen or refrigerated until it is being 
prepped and fed out.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensees. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Moira Roberts, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
